[She]65-mrs. ramsay remembered dressing , and seeing the moon ; [Andrew]71-andrew holding [his]71-andrew plate too high at dinner ; being depressed by something [William]87-william bankes had said ; the birds in the trees ; the sofa on [the landing]548-the landing ; [the children]258-the children being awake ; [Charles Tansley]68-charles tansley waking [them]258-the children with [his]68-charles tansley books falling - oh , no , that [she]65-mrs. ramsay had invented ; and [Paul]78-paul having a wash- leather case for [his]78-paul watch . Which should [she]65-mrs. ramsay tell [him]234-her husband about ?

" [They]1641-they 're engaged , "[65-mrs. ramsay] [she]65-mrs. ramsay said , beginning to knit , " [Paul]78-paul and [Minta]77-minta . "[65-mrs. ramsay]

" So [I]234-her husband guessed , "[234-her husband] [he]234-her husband said . There was nothing very much to be said about it . [Her]65-mrs. ramsay mind was still going up and down , up and down with the poetry ; [he]234-her husband was still feeling very vigorous , very forthright , after reading about [Steenie]168-poor steenie 's funeral . So [they]1641-they sat silent . Then [she]65-mrs. ramsay became aware that [she]65-mrs. ramsay wanted [him]234-her husband to say something .

Anything , anything , [she]65-mrs. ramsay thought , going on with [her]65-mrs. ramsay knitting . Anything will do .

" How nice it would be to marry [a man with a wash - leather bag for [his]291-that young man watch]1601-a man with a wash - leather bag for his watch , "[65-mrs. ramsay] [she]65-mrs. ramsay said , for that was the sort of joke [they]1641-they had together .

[He]234-her husband snorted . [He]234-her husband felt about this engagement as [he]234-her husband always felt about any engagement ; [the girl]241-the girl is much too good for [that young man]291-that young man . Slowly it came into [her]65-mrs. ramsay head , why is it then that [one]222-one wants [people]264-people to marry ? What was the value , the meaning of things ? Every word [they]1641-they said now would be true . Do say something , [she]65-mrs. ramsay thought , wishing only to hear [his]234-her husband voice . For the shadow , the thing folding them in was beginning , [she]65-mrs. ramsay felt , to close round [her]65-mrs. ramsay again . Say anything , [she]65-mrs. ramsay begged , looking at [him]234-her husband , as if for help .

[He]234-her husband was silent , swinging the compass on [his]234-her husband watch - chain to and fro , and thinking of [Scott]157-scott 's novels and [Balzac]48-balzac 's novels . But through the crepuscular walls of [their]1641-they intimacy , for [they]1641-they were drawing together , involuntarily , coming side by side , quite close , [she]65-mrs. ramsay could feel [his]234-her husband mind like a raised hand shadowing [her]65-mrs. ramsay mind ; and [he]234-her husband was beginning , now that [her]65-mrs. ramsay thoughts took a turn [he]234-her husband disliked - towards this " pessimism "[234-her husband] as [he]234-her husband called it - to fidget , though [he]234-her husband said nothing , raising [his]234-her husband hand to [his]234-her husband forehead , twisting a lock of hair , letting it fall again .

" [You]65-mrs. ramsay wo n't finish that stocking tonight , "[234-her husband] [he]234-her husband said , pointing to [her]65-mrs. ramsay stocking . That was what [she]65-mrs. ramsay wanted - the asperity in [his]234-her husband voice reproving [her]65-mrs. ramsay . If [he]234-her husband says it 's wrong to be pessimistic probably it is wrong , [she]65-mrs. ramsay thought ; the marriage will turn out all right .

" No , "[65-mrs. ramsay] [she]65-mrs. ramsay said , flattening the stocking out upon [her]65-mrs. ramsay knee , " [I]65-mrs. ramsay sha n't finish it . "[65-mrs. ramsay]

And what then ? For [she]65-mrs. ramsay felt that [he]234-her husband was still looking at [her]65-mrs. ramsay , but that [his]234-her husband look had changed . [He]234-her husband wanted something - wanted the thing [she]65-mrs. ramsay always found it so difficult to give [him]234-her husband ; wanted [her]65-mrs. ramsay to tell [him]234-her husband that [she]65-mrs. ramsay loved [him]234-her husband . And that , no , [she]65-mrs. ramsay could not do . [He]234-her husband found talking so much easier than [she]65-mrs. ramsay did . [He]234-her husband could say things - [she]65-mrs. ramsay never could . So naturally it was always [he]234-her husband that said the things , and then for some reason [he]234-her husband would mind this suddenly , and would reproach [her]65-mrs. ramsay . [A heartless woman [he]234-her husband called [her]65-mrs. ramsay]1646-a heartless woman he called her ; [she]65-mrs. ramsay never told [him]234-her husband that [she]65-mrs. ramsay loved [him]234-her husband . But it was not so - it was not so . It was only that [she]65-mrs. ramsay never could say what [she]65-mrs. ramsay felt . Was there no crumb on [his]234-her husband coat ? Nothing [she]65-mrs. ramsay could do for [him]234-her husband ? Getting up , [she]65-mrs. ramsay stood at the window with the reddish - brown stocking in [her]65-mrs. ramsay hands , partly to turn away from [him]234-her husband , partly because [she]65-mrs. ramsay remembered how beautiful it often is - [the sea]220-the sea at night . But [she]65-mrs. ramsay knew that [he]234-her husband had turned [his]234-her husband head as [she]65-mrs. ramsay turned ; [he]234-her husband was watching [her]65-mrs. ramsay . [She]65-mrs. ramsay knew that [he]234-her husband was thinking , [You]65-mrs. ramsay are more beautiful than ever . And [she]65-mrs. ramsay felt [herself]65-mrs. ramsay very beautiful . Will [you]234-her husband not tell [me]0-i just for once that [you]234-her husband love [me]0-i ? [He]234-her husband was thinking that , for [he]234-her husband was roused , what with [Minta]77-minta and [his]234-her husband book , and its being the end of the day and [their]1648-their having quarrelled about going to [the Lighthouse]210-the lighthouse . But [she]65-mrs. ramsay could not do it ; [she]65-mrs. ramsay could not say it . Then , knowing that [he]234-her husband was watching [her]65-mrs. ramsay , instead of saying anything [she]65-mrs. ramsay turned , holding [her]65-mrs. ramsay stocking , and looked at [him]234-her husband . And as [she]65-mrs. ramsay looked at [him]234-her husband [she]65-mrs. ramsay began to smile , for though [she]65-mrs. ramsay had not said a word , [he]234-her husband knew , of course [he]234-her husband knew , that [she]65-mrs. ramsay loved [him]234-her husband . [He]234-her husband could not deny it . And smiling [she]65-mrs. ramsay looked out of the window and said thinking to [herself]65-mrs. ramsay , Nothing on [earth]1650-earth can equal this happiness -

" Yes , [you]234-her husband were right . It 's going to be wet tomorrow . [You]234-her husband wo n't be able to go . "[65-mrs. ramsay] And [she]65-mrs. ramsay looked at [him]234-her husband smiling . For [she]65-mrs. ramsay had triumphed again . [She]65-mrs. ramsay had not said it : yet [he]234-her husband knew .

TIME PASSES

1

" Well , [we]2858-we must wait for the future to show , "[90-mr. bankes] said [Mr. Bankes]90-mr. bankes , coming in from [the terrace]225-the terrace .

" It 's almost too dark to see , "[71-andrew] said [Andrew]71-andrew , coming up from [the beach]366-the beach .

" [One]222-one can hardly tell which is [the sea]220-the sea and which is [the land]1070-the land , "[70-prue] said [Prue]70-prue .

" Do [we]2858-we leave that light burning ? "[86-lily] said [Lily]86-lily as [they]1653-they took [their]1653-they coats off [indoors]1654-indoors .

" No , "[70-prue] said [Prue]70-prue , " not if [every one]853-every one 's in . "[70-prue]

" [Andrew]71-andrew , "[65-mrs. ramsay] [she]65-mrs. ramsay called back , " just put out the light in [the hall]914-the hall . "[65-mrs. ramsay]

One by one the lamps were all extinguished , except that [Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael , who liked to lie awake a little reading [Virgil]170-virgil , kept [his]80-mr. carmichael candle burning rather longer than the rest .

2

So with the lamps all put out , the moon sunk , and a thin rain drumming on the roof a downpouring of immense darkness began . Nothing , it seemed , could survive the flood , the profusion of darkness which , creeping in at keyholes and crevices , stole round window blinds , came into [bedrooms]1233-bedrooms , swallowed up here a jug and basin , there a bowl of red and yellow dahlias , there the sharp edges and firm bulk of a chest of drawers . Not only was furniture confounded ; there was scarcely anything left of body or mind by which [one]222-one could say , " This is [he]71-andrew "[222-one] or " This is [she]2864-she . "[222-one] Sometimes a hand was raised as if to clutch something or ward off something , or [somebody]335-somebody groaned , or [somebody]335-somebody laughed aloud as if sharing a joke with nothingness .

Nothing stirred in [the drawing - room]200-the drawing - room or in [the dining - room]279-the dining - room or on the staircase . Only through the rusty hinges and swollen sea - moistened woodwork certain airs , detached from the body of the wind [the house]299-the house was ramshackle after all crept round corners and ventured indoors . Almost one might imagine [them]1653-they , as [they]1653-they entered [the drawing - room]200-the drawing - room questioning and wondering , toying with the flap of hanging wall - paper , asking , would it hang much longer , when would it fall ? Then smoothly brushing the walls , [they]1653-they passed on musingly as if asking the red and yellow roses on the wall - paper whether they would fade , and questioning gently , for there was time at [their]1653-they disposal the torn letters in the wastepaper basket , the flowers , the books , all of which were now open to [them]1653-they and asking , Were [they]1653-they [allies]1663-allies ? Were [they]1653-they [enemies]1664-enemies ? How long would [they]1653-they endure ?

So some random light directing [them]1653-they with its pale footfall upon stair and mat , from some uncovered star , or [wandering ship]1665-wandering ship , or [the Lighthouse]49-the lighthouse even , with its pale footfall upon stair and mat , the little airs mounted the staircase and nosed round bedroom doors . But here surely , [they]1653-they must cease . Whatever else may perish and disappear , what lies [here]361-here is steadfast . Here one might say to those sliding lights , those fumbling airs that breathe and bend over the bed itself , here [you]1667-you can neither touch nor destroy . Upon which , wearily , ghostlily , as if [they]1653-they had feather - light fingers and the light persistency of feathers , [they]1653-they would look , once , on the shut eyes , and the loosely clasping fingers , and fold [their]1653-they garments wearily and disappear . And so , nosing , rubbing , [they]1653-they went to the window on [the staircase]1668-the staircase , to [[the servants]1669-the servants ' bedrooms]1670-the servants ' bedrooms , to the boxes in [the attics]1552-the attics ; descending , blanched the apples on the dining - room table , fumbled the petals of roses , tried the picture on the easel , brushed the mat and blew a little sand along the floor . At length , desisting , all ceased together , gathered together , all sighed together ; all together gave off an aimless gust of lamentation to which some door in [the kitchen]677-the kitchen replied ; swung wide ; admitted nothing ; and slammed to .

Here [Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael , who was reading [Virgil]170-virgil , blew out [his]80-mr. carmichael candle . It was past midnight .

3

But what after all is one night ? A short space , especially when the darkness dims so soon , and so soon a bird sings , a cock crows , or a faint green quickens , like a turning leaf , in the hollow of the wave . Night , however , succeeds to night . The winter holds a pack of them in store and deals [them]1673-them equally , evenly , with indefatigable fingers . They lengthen ; they darken . Some of [them]1673-them hold aloft clear planets , plates of brightness . The autumn trees , ravaged as they are , take on the flash of tattered flags kindling in the gloom of cool cathedral caves where gold letters on marble pages describe death in battle and how bones bleach and burn far away in Indian sands . [The autumn trees]1674-the autumn trees gleam in the yellow moonlight , in the light of harvest moons , the light which mellows the energy of labour , and smooths the stubble , and brings the wave lapping blue to [the shore]1155-the shore .

It seemed now as if , touched by human penitence and all its toil , divine goodness had parted the curtain and displayed behind it , single , distinct , the hare erect ; the wave falling ; [the boat]1676-the boat rocking ; which , did [we]1677-we deserve them , should be ours always . But alas , [divine goodness]1678-divine goodness , twitching the cord , draws the curtain ; it does not please [him]80-mr. carmichael ; [he]80-mr. carmichael covers [his]80-mr. carmichael treasures in a drench of hail , and so breaks them , so confuses [them]1673-them that it seems impossible that [their]1673-them calm should ever return or that [we]1677-we should ever compose from [their]1673-them fragments a perfect whole or read in the littered pieces the clear words of truth . For [our]1677-we penitence deserves a glimpse only ; [our]1677-we toil respite only .

The nights now are full of wind and destruction ; the trees plunge and bend and their leaves fly helter skelter until the lawn is plastered with them and they lie packed in gutters and choke rain pipes and scatter damp paths . Also [the sea]220-the sea tosses itself and breaks itself , and should [any sleeper]1680-any sleeper fancying that [he]1680-any sleeper might find on [the beach]366-the beach an answer to [his]1680-any sleeper doubts , [a sharer of [his]1680-any sleeper solitude]1682-a sharer of his solitude , throw off [his]1680-any sleeper bedclothes and go down by [himself]1680-any sleeper to walk on [the sand]1683-the sand , no image with semblance of serving and divine promptitude comes readily to hand bringing the night to order and making [the world]300-the world reflect the compass of the soul . The hand dwindles in [his]1680-any sleeper hand ; the voice bellows in [his]1680-any sleeper ear . Almost it would appear that it is useless in such confusion to ask the night those questions as to what , and why , and wherefore , which tempt [the sleeper]1685-the sleeper from [his]1680-any sleeper bed to seek an answer .

[Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay , stumbling along [a passage]1686-a passage one dark morning , stretched [his]67-mr. ramsay arms out , but [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay having died rather suddenly the night before , [his]67-mr. ramsay arms , though stretched out , remained empty .

4

So with [the house]299-the house empty and the doors locked and the mattresses rolled round , those stray airs , [advance guards of great armies]1688-advance guards of great armies , blustered in , brushed bare boards , nibbled and fanned , met nothing in [bedroom]834-bedroom or [drawing - room that wholly resisted]1690-drawing - room that wholly resisted [them]1691-them but only hangings that flapped , wood that creaked , the bare legs of tables , saucepans and china already furred , tarnished , cracked . What [people]264-people had shed and left - a pair of shoes , a shooting cap , some faded skirts and coats in wardrobes - those alone kept the human shape and in the emptiness indicated how once they were filled and animated ; how once hands were busy with hooks and buttons ; how once the looking - glass had held a face ; had held a world hollowed out in which a figure turned , a hand flashed , the door opened , in came [children rushing and tumbling]1693-children rushing and tumbling ; and went out again . Now , day after day , light turned , like a flower reflected in water , its sharp image on the wall opposite . Only the shadows of the trees , flourishing in the wind , made obeisance on the wall , and for a moment darkened the pool in which light reflected itself ; or birds , flying , made a soft spot flutter slowly across the bedroom floor .

So loveliness reigned and stillness , and together made the shape of loveliness itself , a form from which life had parted ; solitary like a pool at evening , far distant , seen from a train window , vanishing so quickly that the pool , pale in the evening , is scarcely robbed of [its]1694-its solitude , though once seen . Loveliness and stillness clasped hands in [the bedroom]1695-the bedroom , and among the shrouded jugs and sheeted chairs even the prying of the wind , and the soft nose of the clammy sea airs , rubbing , snuffling , iterating , and reiterating [their]1691-them questions - " Will [you]2865-you fade ? Will [you]2865-you perish ? "[1691-them] - scarcely disturbed the peace , the indifference , the air of pure integrity , as if the question [they]1691-them asked scarcely needed that [they]1691-them should answer : [we]1696-we remain .

Nothing it seemed could break that image , corrupt that innocence , or disturb the swaying mantle of silence which , week after week , in [the empty room]1697-the empty room , wove into itself the falling cries of birds , ships hooting , the drone and hum of [the fields]762-the fields , a dog 's bark , [a man]1103-a man 's shout , and folded [them]1691-them round [the house]299-the house in silence . Once only a board sprang on [the landing]548-the landing ; once in the middle of the night with a roar , with a rupture , as after centuries of quiescence , a rock rends itself from [the mountain]1702-the mountain and hurtles crashing into [the valley]1703-the valley , one fold of the shawl loosened and swung to and fro . Then again peace descended ; and the shadow wavered ; light bent to its own image in adoration on the bedroom wall ; and [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab , tearing the veil of silence with hands that had stood in the wash - tub , grinding it with boots that had crunched the shingle , came as directed to open all windows , and dust [the bedrooms]679-the bedrooms .

5

As [she]171-mrs. mcnab lurched for [she]171-mrs. mcnab rolled like [a ship at]1705-a ship at [sea]1706-sea and leered for [her]171-mrs. mcnab eyes fell on nothing directly , but with a sidelong glance that deprecated the scorn and anger of [the world]300-the world - [she]171-mrs. mcnab was witless , [she]171-mrs. mcnab knew it , as [she]171-mrs. mcnab clutched the banisters and hauled [herself]171-mrs. mcnab [upstairs]375-upstairs and rolled from [room]1709-room to [room]1709-room , [she]171-mrs. mcnab sang . Rubbing the glass of the long looking - glass and leering sideways at [her]171-mrs. mcnab swinging figure a sound issued from [her]171-mrs. mcnab lips - something that had been gay twenty years before on the stage perhaps , had been hummed and danced to , but now , coming from [the toothless , bonneted , care - taking woman]1711-the toothless , bonneted , care - taking woman , was robbed of meaning , was like the voice of witlessness , humour , persistency itself , trodden down but springing up again , so that as [she]171-mrs. mcnab lurched , dusting , wiping , [she]171-mrs. mcnab seemed to say how it was one long sorrow and trouble , how it was getting up and going to bed again , and bringing things out and putting them away again . It was not easy or snug [this world]489-this world [she]171-mrs. mcnab had known for close on seventy years . Bowed down [she]171-mrs. mcnab was with weariness . How long , [she]171-mrs. mcnab asked , creaking and groaning on [her]171-mrs. mcnab knees under the bed , dusting the boards , how long shall it endure ? but hobbled to [her]171-mrs. mcnab feet again , pulled [herself]171-mrs. mcnab up , and again with [her]171-mrs. mcnab sidelong leer which slipped and turned aside even from [her]171-mrs. mcnab own face , and [her]171-mrs. mcnab own sorrows , stood and gaped in the glass , aimlessly smiling , and began again the old amble and hobble , taking up mats , putting down china , looking sideways in the glass , as if , after all , [she]171-mrs. mcnab had [her]171-mrs. mcnab consolations , as if indeed there twined about [her]171-mrs. mcnab dirge some incorrigible hope . Visions of joy there must have been at the wash- tub , say with [[her]171-mrs. mcnab children]278-her children yet two had been [base - born]1714-base - born and one had deserted [her]171-mrs. mcnab , at [the public - house]1715-the public - house , drinking ; turning over scraps in [her]171-mrs. mcnab drawers . Some cleavage of the dark there must have been , some channel in the depths of obscurity through which light enough issued to twist [her]171-mrs. mcnab face grinning in the glass and make [her]171-mrs. mcnab , turning to [her]171-mrs. mcnab job again , mumble out the old music hall song . [The mystic]1716-the mystic , [the visionary]1717-the visionary , walking [the beach]366-the beach on a fine night , stirring a puddle , looking at a stone , asking [themselves]278-her children " What am [I]1717-the visionary , "[1717-the visionary] " What is this ? "[1717-the visionary] had suddenly an answer vouchsafed [them]278-her children : [they]278-her children could not say what it was so that [they]278-her children were warm in the frost and had comfort in [the desert]1719-the desert . But [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab continued to drink and gossip as before .

6

The Spring without a leaf to toss , bare and bright like a virgin fierce in [her]171-mrs. mcnab chastity , scornful in [her]171-mrs. mcnab purity , was laid out on fields wide- eyed and watchful and entirely careless of what was done or thought by [the beholders]1720-the beholders . [Prue Ramsay]70-prue , leaning on [[her]171-mrs. mcnab father]274-her father 's arm , was given in marriage . What , [people]264-people said , could have been more fitting ? And , [they]264-people added , how beautiful [she]171-mrs. mcnab looked !

As summer neared , as the evenings lengthened , there came to the wakeful , the hopeful , walking [the beach]366-the beach , stirring the pool , imaginations of the strangest kind - of flesh turned to atoms which drove before the wind , of stars flashing in [their]264-people hearts , of cliff , [sea]1706-sea , cloud , and sky brought purposely together to assemble outwardly the scattered parts of the vision within . In those mirrors , the minds of [men]358-men , in those pools of uneasy water , in which clouds for ever turn and shadows form , dreams persisted , and it was impossible to resist the strange intimation which every gull , flower , tree , [man]311-man and [woman]1437-woman , and [the white earth]1728-the white earth itself seemed to declare but if questioned at once to withdraw that good triumphs , happiness prevails , order rules ; or to resist the extraordinary stimulus to range hither and thither in search of some absolute good , some crystal of intensity , remote from the known pleasures and familiar virtues , something alien to the processes of domestic life , single , hard , bright , like a diamond in the sand , which would render [the possessor]1729-the possessor secure . Moreover , softened and acquiescent , the spring with [her]171-mrs. mcnab bees humming and gnats dancing threw [her]171-mrs. mcnab cloak about [her]171-mrs. mcnab , veiled [her]171-mrs. mcnab eyes , averted [her]171-mrs. mcnab head , and among passing shadows and flights of small rain seemed to have taken upon [her]171-mrs. mcnab a knowledge of the sorrows of [mankind]1730-mankind .

[Prue Ramsay]70-prue died that summer in some illness connected with childbirth , which was indeed a tragedy , [people]264-people said , everything , [they]264-people said , had promised so well .

And now in the heat of summer the wind sent its spies about [the house]299-the house again . Flies wove a web in [the sunny rooms]1733-the sunny rooms ; weeds that had grown close to the glass in the night tapped methodically at the window pane . When darkness fell , the stroke of the Lighthouse , which had laid itself with such authority upon the carpet in the darkness , tracing its pattern , came now in the softer light of spring mixed with moonlight gliding gently as if it laid its caress and lingered steathily and looked and came lovingly again . But in the very lull of this loving caress , as the long stroke leant upon the bed , the rock was rent asunder ; another fold of the shawl loosened ; there it hung , and swayed . Through the short summer nights and the long summer days , when [the empty rooms]1734-the empty rooms seemed to murmur with the echoes of the fields and the hum of flies , the long streamer waved gently , swayed aimlessly ; while the sun so striped and barred [the rooms]1735-the rooms and filled [them]1735-the rooms with yellow haze that [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab , when [she]171-mrs. mcnab broke in and lurched about , dusting , sweeping , looked like a tropical fish oaring its way through sun - lanced waters .

But slumber and sleep though it might there came later in the summer ominous sounds like the measured blows of hammers dulled on felt , which , with their repeated shocks still further loosened the shawl and cracked the tea - cups . Now and again some glass tinkled in the cupboard as if a giant voice had shrieked so loud in its agony that tumblers stood inside a cupboard vibrated too . Then again silence fell ; and then , night after night , and sometimes in plain mid - day when the roses were bright and light turned on the wall its shape clearly there seemed to drop into this silence , this indifference , this integrity , the thud of something falling .

A shell exploded . [Twenty or thirty young men]1736-twenty or thirty young men were blown up in [France]50-france , among [them]1736-twenty or thirty young men [Andrew Ramsay]71-andrew , whose death , mercifully , was instantaneous .

At that season [those who had gone down to pace [the beach]366-the beach and ask of [the sea]220-the sea and sky what message [they]264-people reported or what vision [they]264-people affirmed]1737-those who had gone down to pace the beach and ask of the sea and sky what message they reported or what vision they affirmed had to consider among the usual tokens of divine bounty - the sunset on [the sea]220-the sea , the pallor of dawn , the moon rising , fishing - boats against the moon , and [children making mud pies or pelting each other with handfuls of grass]1741-children making mud pies or pelting each other with handfuls of grass , something out of harmony with this jocundity and this serenity . There was the silent apparition of [an ashen - coloured ship]1742-an ashen - coloured ship for instance , come , gone ; there was a purplish stain upon the bland surface of [the sea]220-the sea as if something had boiled and bled , invisibly , beneath . This intrusion into a scene calculated to stir the most sublime reflections and lead to the most comfortable conclusions stayed [their]264-people pacing . It was difficult blandly to overlook them ; to abolish their significance in [the landscape]1744-the landscape ; to continue , as [one]222-one walked by [the sea]220-the sea , to marvel how beauty outside mirrored beauty within .

Did [Nature]102-nature supplement what [man]311-man advanced ? Did [she]171-mrs. mcnab complete what [he]311-man began ? With equal complacence [she]171-mrs. mcnab saw [his]311-man misery , [his]311-man meanness , and [his]311-man torture . That dream , of sharing , completing , of finding in solitude on [the beach]366-the beach an answer , was then but a reflection in a mirror , and the mirror itself was but the surface glassiness which forms in quiescence when the nobler powers sleep beneath ? [Impatient]172-impatient , despairing yet loth to go for beauty offers [her]171-mrs. mcnab lures , has [her]171-mrs. mcnab consolations , to pace [the beach]366-the beach was impossible ; contemplation was unendurable ; the mirror was broken .

[Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael brought out a volume of poems that spring , which had an unexpected success . The war , [people]264-people said , had revived [their]264-people interest in poetry .

7

Night after night , summer and winter , the torment of storms , the arrow- like stillness of fine had there been any one to listen from [the upper rooms of [the empty house]1752-the empty house]1751-the upper rooms of the empty house only gigantic chaos streaked with lightning could have been heard tumbling and tossing , as the winds and waves disported themselves like the amorphous bulks of [leviathans whose brows are pierced by no light of reason]1753-leviathans whose brows are pierced by no light of reason , and mounted [one on top of another , and lunged and plunged in the darkness]1754-one on top of another , and lunged and plunged in the darkness or the daylight for night and day , month and year ran shapelessly together in idiot games , until it seemed as if [the universe]1755-the universe were battling and tumbling , in brute confusion and wanton lust aimlessly by itself .

In spring the garden urns , casually filled with wind - blown plants , were gay as ever . Violets came and daffodils . But the stillness and the brightness of the day were as strange as the chaos and tumult of night , with the trees standing there , and the flowers standing there , looking before them , looking up , yet beholding nothing , eyeless , and so terrible .

8

Thinking no harm , for [the family]1756-the family would not come , never again , [some]1757-some said , and [the house]299-the house would be sold at [Michaelmas]51-michaelmas perhaps , [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab stooped and picked a bunch of flowers to take [home]378-home with [her]171-mrs. mcnab . [She]171-mrs. mcnab laid them on the table while [she]171-mrs. mcnab dusted . [She]171-mrs. mcnab was fond of flowers . It was a pity to let them waste . Suppose [the house]299-the house were sold [she]171-mrs. mcnab stood arms akimbo in front of the looking - glass it would want seeing to - it would . [There]236-there [it]299-the house had stood all these years without a soul in it . The books and things were mouldy , for , what with the war and help being hard to get , [the house]299-the house had not been cleaned as [she]171-mrs. mcnab could have wished . It was beyond [one person]1763-one person 's strength to get it straight now . [She]171-mrs. mcnab was too old . [Her]171-mrs. mcnab legs pained [her]171-mrs. mcnab . All those books needed to be laid out on the grass in the sun ; there was plaster fallen in [the hall]914-the hall ; the rain - pipe had blocked over the study window and let the water in ; the carpet was ruined quite . But [people]264-people should come [themselves]264-people ; [they]264-people should have sent [somebody]335-somebody down to see . For there were clothes in the cupboards ; [they]264-people had left clothes in all [the bedrooms]679-the bedrooms . What was [she]171-mrs. mcnab to do with [them]1768-them ? [They]1768-them had the moth in [them]1768-them - [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay 's things . [Poor lady]1769-poor lady ! [She]65-mrs. ramsay would never want [THEM]1768-them again . [She]65-mrs. ramsay was dead , [they]264-people said ; years ago , in [London]11-london . There was the old grey cloak [she]65-mrs. ramsay wore gardening [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab fingered it . [She]171-mrs. mcnab could see [her]65-mrs. ramsay , as [she]65-mrs. ramsay came up [the drive]478-the drive with the washing , stooping over [her]65-mrs. ramsay flowers [the garden]371-the garden was a pitiful sight now , all run to riot , and rabbits scuttling at [you]1772-you out of the beds - [she]171-mrs. mcnab could see [her]65-mrs. ramsay with one of [the children]258-the children by [her]65-mrs. ramsay in that grey cloak . There were boots and shoes ; and a brush and comb left on the dressing - table , for all [the world]300-the world as if [she]65-mrs. ramsay expected to come back tomorrow . [She]65-mrs. ramsay had died very sudden at the end , [they]264-people said . And once [they]264-people had been coming , but had put off coming , what with the war , and travel being so difficult these days ; [they]264-people had never come all these years ; just sent [her]65-mrs. ramsay money ; but never wrote , never came , and expected to find things as [they]264-people had left them , ah , [dear]2764-dear ! Why the dressing - table drawers were full of things [she]171-mrs. mcnab pulled them open , handkerchiefs , bits of ribbon . Yes , [she]171-mrs. mcnab could see [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay as [she]171-mrs. mcnab came up [the drive]478-the drive with the washing .

" Good - evening , [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab , "[171-mrs. mcnab] [she]171-mrs. mcnab would say .

[She]171-mrs. mcnab had a pleasant way with [her]171-mrs. mcnab . [The girls]1777-the girls all liked [her]171-mrs. mcnab . But , [dear]2764-dear , many things had changed since then [she]171-mrs. mcnab shut the drawer ; [many families]1779-many families had lost [their]1779-many families dearest . So [she]171-mrs. mcnab was dead ; and [Mr. Andrew]173-andrew killed ; and [Miss Prue]174-miss prue dead too , [they]1777-the girls said , with [[her]174-miss prue first baby]1780-her first baby ; but [everyone]1781-everyone had lost some one these years . [Prices]175-prices had gone up shamefully , and did n't come down again neither . [She]171-mrs. mcnab could well remember [her]171-mrs. mcnab in [her]171-mrs. mcnab grey cloak .

" Good - evening , [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab , "[171-mrs. mcnab] [she]171-mrs. mcnab said , and told [cook]1782-cook to keep a plate of milk soup for [her]171-mrs. mcnab - quite thought [she]171-mrs. mcnab wanted it , carrying that heavy basket all the way up from [town]1783-town . [She]171-mrs. mcnab could see [her]171-mrs. mcnab now , stooping over [her]171-mrs. mcnab flowers ; and faint and flickering , like a yellow beam or the circle at the end of a telescope , [a lady in a grey cloak]1784-a lady in a grey cloak , stooping over [her]171-mrs. mcnab flowers , went wandering over the bedroom wall , up the dressing - table , across the wash - stand , as [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab hobbled and ambled , dusting , straightening . And cook 's name now ? [Mildred]117-mildred ? [Marian]137-mary ? - some name like that . Ah , [she]171-mrs. mcnab had forgotten - [she]171-mrs. mcnab did forget things . [Fiery]176-fiery , like [all red - haired women]1785-all red - haired women . Many a laugh [they]1785-all red - haired women had had . [She]171-mrs. mcnab was always welcome in [the kitchen]677-the kitchen . [She]171-mrs. mcnab made [them]1785-all red - haired women laugh , [she]171-mrs. mcnab did . Things were better then than now .

[She]171-mrs. mcnab sighed ; there was too much work for [one woman]1787-one woman . [She]171-mrs. mcnab wagged [her]171-mrs. mcnab head this side and that . This had been [the nursery]1788-the nursery . Why , it was all damp in here ; the plaster was falling . Whatever did [they]1785-all red - haired women want to hang a beast 's skull there ? gone mouldy too . And rats in all [the attics]1552-the attics . The rain came in . But [they]1785-all red - haired women never sent ; never came . Some of the locks had gone , so the doors banged . [She]171-mrs. mcnab did n't like to be up [here]361-here at dusk alone neither . It was too much for [one woman]1787-one woman , too much , too much . [She]171-mrs. mcnab creaked , [she]171-mrs. mcnab moaned . [She]171-mrs. mcnab banged the door . [She]171-mrs. mcnab turned the key in the lock , and left [the house]299-the house alone , shut up , locked .

9

[The house]299-the house was left ; [the house]299-the house was deserted . [It]299-the house was left like a shell on a sandhill to fill with dry salt grains now that life had left [it]299-the house . The long night seemed to have set in ; the trifling airs , nibbling , the clammy breaths , fumbling , seemed to have triumphed . The saucepan had rusted and the mat decayed . [Toads]177-toads had nosed [their]177-toads way in . Idly , aimlessly , the swaying shawl swung to and fro . A thistle thrust itself between the tiles in the larder . The swallows nested in the drawing- roon ; the floor was strewn with straw ; the plaster fell in shovelfuls ; rafters were laid bare ; rats carried off this and that to gnaw behind [the wainscots]1795-the wainscots . Tortoise - shell butterflies burst from the chrysalis and pattered their life out on the window - pane . Poppies sowed themselves among [the dahlias]1796-the dahlias ; [the lawn]310-the lawn waved with long grass ; giant artichokes towered among roses ; a fringed carnation flowered among the cabbages ; while the gentle tapping of a weed at the window had become , on winters ' nights , a drumming from sturdy trees and thorned briars which made [the whole room]544-the whole room green in summer .

What power could now prevent the fertility , the insensibility of nature ? [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab 's dream of [a lady]1799-a lady , of [a child]381-a child , of a plate of milk soup ? It had wavered over the walls like a spot of sunlight and vanished . [She]171-mrs. mcnab had locked the door ; [she]171-mrs. mcnab had gone . It was beyond the strength of [one woman]1787-one woman , [she]171-mrs. mcnab said . [They]1802-they never sent . [They]1802-they never wrote . There were things up there rotting in the drawers - it was a shame to leave them so , [she]171-mrs. mcnab said . [The place]888-the place was gone to rack and ruin . Only the Lighthouse beam entered [the rooms]1735-the rooms for a moment , sent its sudden stare over bed and wall in the darkness of winter , looked with equanimity at the thistle and the swallow , the rat and the straw . Nothing now withstood [them]1802-they ; nothing said no to [them]1802-they . Let the wind blow ; let the poppy seed itself and the carnation mate with the cabbage . Let the swallow build in [the drawing - room]200-the drawing - room , and the thistle thrust aside the tiles , and the butterfly sun itself on the faded chintz of the arm - chairs . Let the broken glass and the china lie out on [the lawn]310-the lawn and be tangled over with grass and wild berries .

For now had come that moment , that hesitation when dawn trembles and night pauses , when if a feather alight in the scale it will be weighed down . One feather , and [the house]299-the house , sinking , falling , would have turned and pitched downwards to the depths of darkness . In [the ruined room]1808-the ruined room , [picnickers]1809-picnickers would have lit [their]1809-picnickers kettles ; [lovers]1810-lovers sought shelter there , lying on the bare boards ; and [the shepherd]1811-the shepherd stored [his]1811-the shepherd dinner on the bricks , and [the tramp]1812-the tramp slept with [his]1812-the tramp coat round [him]1812-the tramp to ward off the cold . Then the roof would have fallen ; briars and hemlocks would have blotted out path , step and window ; would have grown , unequally but lustily over the mound , until [some trespasser]1813-some trespasser , losing [his]1813-some trespasser way , could have told only by a red - hot poker among the nettles , or a scrap of china in the hemlock , that here once [some one]386-some one had lived ; there had been [a house]546-a house .

If the feather had fallen , if it had tipped the scale downwards , [the whole house]1816-the whole house would have plunged to the depths to lie upon [the sands of oblivion]1817-the sands of oblivion . But there was a force working ; something not highly conscious ; something that leered , something that lurched ; something not inspired to go about its work with dignified ritual or solemn chanting . [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab groaned ; [Mrs. Bast]178-mrs. bast creaked . [They]1818-they were old ; [they]1818-they were stiff ; [their]1818-they legs ached . [They]1818-they came with [their]1818-they brooms and pails at last ; [they]1818-they got to work . All of a sudden , would [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab see that [the house]299-the house was ready , [one of [the young ladies]1821-the young ladies]1820-one of the young ladies wrote : would [she]171-mrs. mcnab get this done ; would [she]171-mrs. mcnab get that done ; all in a hurry . [They]1818-they might be coming for the summer ; had left everything to the last ; expected to find things as [they]1818-they had left [them]1822-them . Slowly and painfully , with broom and pail , mopping , scouring , [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab , [Mrs. Bast]178-mrs. bast , stayed the corruption and the rot ; rescued from the pool of Time that was fast closing over [them]1818-they now a basin , now a cupboard ; fetched up from oblivion all the Waverley novels and a tea - set one morning ; in the afternoon restored to sun and air a brass fender and a set of steel fire - irons . [George]147-george , [[Mrs. Bast]178-mrs. bast 's son]1823-mrs. bast 's son , caught the rats , and cut the grass . [They]1818-they had [the builders]1824-the builders . Attended with the creaking of hinges and the screeching of bolts , the slamming and banging of damp - swollen woodwork , some rusty laborious birth seemed to be taking place , as [the women , stooping , rising , groaning , singing]1825-the women , stooping , rising , groaning , singing , slapped and slammed , [upstairs]375-upstairs now , now down in [the cellars]1827-the cellars . Oh , [they]1818-they said , the work !

[They]1818-they drank [their]1818-they tea in [the bedroom]1695-the bedroom sometimes , or in [the study]1829-the study ; breaking off work at mid - day with the smudge on [their]1818-they faces , and [their]1818-they old hands clasped and cramped with the broom handles . Flopped on chairs , [they]1818-they contemplated now the magnificent conquest over taps and bath ; now the more arduous , more partial triumph over long rows of books , black as ravens once , now white - stained , breeding pale mushrooms and secreting furtive spiders . Once more , as [she]171-mrs. mcnab felt the tea warm in [her]171-mrs. mcnab , the telescope fitted itself to [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab 's eyes , and in a ring of light [she]171-mrs. mcnab saw [the old gentleman , lean as a rake]1830-the old gentleman , lean as a rake , wagging [his]1830-the old gentleman , lean as a rake head , as [she]171-mrs. mcnab came up with the washing , talking to [himself]1830-the old gentleman , lean as a rake , [she]171-mrs. mcnab supposed , on [the lawn]310-the lawn . [He]1830-the old gentleman , lean as a rake never noticed [her]171-mrs. mcnab . [Some]1757-some said [he]1830-the old gentleman , lean as a rake was dead ; [some]1757-some said [she]171-mrs. mcnab was dead . Which was it ? [Mrs. Bast]178-mrs. bast did n't know for certain either . [The young gentleman]1834-the young gentleman was dead . That [she]171-mrs. mcnab was sure . [She]171-mrs. mcnab had read [his]1834-the young gentleman name in the papers .

There was [the cook]904-the cook now , [Mildred]117-mildred , [Marian]137-mary , some such name as that - [a red- headed woman , quick - tempered like all [her]1836-a red- headed woman , quick - tempered like all her sort sort]1836-a red- headed woman , quick - tempered like all her sort , but kind , too , if [you]1837-you knew the way with [her]1836-a red- headed woman , quick - tempered like all her sort . Many a laugh [they]1838-they had had together . [She]171-mrs. mcnab saved a plate of soup for [Maggie]163-daisy ; a bite of ham , sometimes ; whatever was over . [They]1838-they lived well in those days . [They]1838-they had everything [they]1838-they wanted glibly , jovially , with the tea hot in [her]171-mrs. mcnab , [she]171-mrs. mcnab unwound [her]171-mrs. mcnab ball of memories , sitting in the wicker arm - chair by the nursery fender . There was always plenty doing , [[people]264-people in [the house]299-the house]1840-people in the house , twenty staying sometimes , and washing up till long past midnight .

[Mrs. Bast]178-mrs. bast [she]178-mrs. bast had never known [them]1838-they ; had lived in [Glasgow]52-glasgow at that time wondered , putting [her]171-mrs. mcnab cup down , whatever [they]1838-they hung that beast 's skull there for ? Shot in foreign parts no doubt .

It might well be , said [Mrs. McNab]171-mrs. mcnab , wantoning on with [her]171-mrs. mcnab memories ; [they]1838-they had [friends]1296-friends in [eastern countries]1843-eastern countries ; [gentlemen]1844-gentlemen staying [there]236-there , [ladies in evening dress]1846-ladies in evening dress ; [she]171-mrs. mcnab had seen [them]1838-they once through the dining - room door all sitting at dinner . Twenty [she]171-mrs. mcnab dared say all in [their]1838-they jewellery , and [she]171-mrs. mcnab asked to stay help wash up , might be till after midnight .

Ah , said [Mrs. Bast]178-mrs. bast , [they]1838-they 'd find it changed . [She]171-mrs. mcnab leant out of the window . [She]171-mrs. mcnab watched [[her]171-mrs. mcnab son]193-her son [George]147-george scything the grass . [They]1838-they might well ask , what had been done to it ? seeing how old [Kennedy]125-kennedy was supposed to have charge of it , and then [his]125-kennedy leg got so bad after [he]125-kennedy fell from the cart ; and perhaps then [no one]477-no one for a year , or the better part of one ; and then [Davie Macdonald]179-davie macdonald , and seeds might be sent , but who should say if they were ever planted ? [They]1838-they 'd find it changed .

[She]171-mrs. mcnab watched [[her]171-mrs. mcnab son]193-her son scything . [He]193-her son was [a great one for work]1850-a great one for work - one of [those quiet ones]1851-those quiet ones . Well [they]1838-they must be getting along with the cupboards , [she]171-mrs. mcnab supposed . [They]1838-they hauled [themselves]1838-they up .

At last , after days of labour within , of cutting and digging without , dusters were flicked from the windows , the windows were shut to , keys were turned all over [the house]299-the house ; the front door was banged ; it was finished .

And now as if the cleaning and the scrubbing and the scything and the mowing had drowned it there rose that half - heard melody , that intermittent music which the ear half catches but lets fall ; a bark , a bleat ; irregular , intermittent , yet somehow related ; the hum of an insect , the tremor of cut grass , disevered yet somehow belonging ; the jar of a dorbeetle , the squeak of a wheel , loud , low , but mysteriously related ; which the ear strains to bring together and is always on the verge of harmonising , but they are never quite heard , never fully harmonised , and at last , in the evening , one after another the sounds die out , and the harmony falters , and silence falls . With the sunset sharpness was lost , and like mist rising , quiet rose , quiet spread , the wind settled ; loosely [the world]300-the world shook [itself]300-the world down to sleep , darkly here without a light to it , save what came green suffused through leaves , or pale on the white flowers in the bed by the window .

[Lily Briscoe]86-lily had [her]86-lily bag carried up to [the house]299-the house late one evening in September . [Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael came by [the same train]1855-the same train .

10

Then indeed peace had come . Messages of peace breathed from [the sea]220-the sea to [the shore]1155-the shore . Never to break its sleep any more , to lull it rather more deeply to rest , and whatever [the dreamers]1858-the dreamers dreamt holily , dreamt wisely , to confirm - what else was it murmuring - as [Lily Briscoe]86-lily laid [her]86-lily head on the pillow in [the clean still room]1859-the clean still room and heard [the sea]220-the sea . Through the open window the voice of the beauty of [the world]300-the world came murmuring , too softly to hear exactly what it said - but what mattered if the meaning were plain ? entreating [the sleepers]1862-the sleepers [the house]299-the house was full again ; [Mrs. Beckwith]180-mrs. beckwith was staying [there]236-there , also [Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael , if [they]1862-the sleepers would not actually come down to [the beach]366-the beach itself at least to lift the blind and look out . [They]1862-the sleepers would see then night flowing down in purple ; [his]80-mr. carmichael head crowned ; [his]80-mr. carmichael sceptre jewelled ; and how in [his]80-mr. carmichael eyes [a child]381-a child might look . And if [they]1862-the sleepers still faltered [Lily]86-lily was tired out with travelling and slept almost at once ; but [Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael read a book by candlelight , if [they]1862-the sleepers still said no , that it was vapour , this splendour of [his]80-mr. carmichael , and the dew had more power than [he]80-mr. carmichael , and [they]1862-the sleepers preferred sleeping ; gently then without complaint , or argument , the voice would sing its song . Gently the waves would break [Lily]86-lily heard [them]1862-the sleepers in [her]86-lily sleep ; tenderly the light fell it seemed to come through [her]86-lily eyelids . And it all looked , [Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael thought , shutting [his]80-mr. carmichael book , falling asleep , much as it used to look .

Indeed the voice might resume , as the curtains of dark wrapped themselves over [the house]299-the house , over [Mrs. Beckwith]180-mrs. beckwith , [Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael , and [Lily Briscoe]86-lily so that [they]1862-the sleepers lay with several folds of blackness on [their]1862-the sleepers eyes , why not accept this , be content with this , acquiesce and resign ? The sigh of all the seas breaking in measure round [the isles]1868-the isles soothed [them]1862-the sleepers ; the night wrapped [them]1862-the sleepers ; nothing broke [their]1862-the sleepers sleep , until , the birds beginning and the dawn weaving [their]1862-the sleepers thin voices in to its whiteness , a cart grinding , a dog somewhere barking , the sun lifted the curtains , broke the veil on [their]1862-the sleepers eyes , and [Lily Briscoe]86-lily stirring in [her]86-lily sleep . [She]86-lily clutched at [her]86-lily blankets as a faller clutches at the turf on [the edge of [a cliff]1041-a cliff]1869-the edge of a cliff . [Her]86-lily eyes opened wide . Here [she]86-lily was again , [she]86-lily thought , sitting bold upright in bed . Awake .

[THE LIGHTHOUSE]210-the lighthouse

1

What does it mean then , what can it all mean ? [Lily Briscoe]86-lily asked [herself]86-lily , wondering whether , since [she]86-lily had been left alone , it behoved [her]86-lily to go to [the kitchen]677-the kitchen to fetch another cup of coffee or wait [here]361-here . What does it mean ? - a catchword that was , caught up from some book , fitting [her]86-lily thought loosely , for [she]86-lily could not , this first morning with [the Ramsays]82-the ramsays , contract [her]86-lily feelings , could only make a phrase resound to cover the blankness of [her]86-lily mind until these vapours had shrunk . For really , what did [she]86-lily feel , come back after all these years and [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay dead ? Nothing , nothing - nothing that [she]86-lily could express at all .

[She]86-lily had come late last night when it was all mysterious , dark . Now [she]86-lily was awake , at [[her]86-lily old place]1874-her old place at the breakfast table , but alone . It was very early too , not yet eight . There was this expedition - [they]1875-they were going to [the Lighthouse]210-the lighthouse , [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay , [Cam]91-cam , and [James]138-james . [They]1875-they should have gone already - [they]1875-they had to catch the tide or something . And [Cam]91-cam was not ready and [James]138-james was not ready and [Nancy]75-nancy had forgotten to order the sandwiches and [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay had lost [his]67-mr. ramsay temper and banged out of [the room]213-the room .

" What 's the use of going now ? "[67-mr. ramsay] [he]67-mr. ramsay had stormed .

[Nancy]75-nancy had vanished . There [he]67-mr. ramsay was , marching up and down [the terrace]225-the terrace in a rage . [One]222-one seemed to hear doors slamming and voices calling all over [the house]299-the house . Now [Nancy]75-nancy burst in , and asked , looking round [the room]213-the room , in a queer half dazed , half desperate way , " What does one send to [the Lighthouse]210-the lighthouse ? "[75-nancy] as if [she]75-nancy were forcing [herself]75-nancy to do what [she]75-nancy despaired of ever being able to do .

What does one send to [the Lighthouse]210-the lighthouse indeed ! At any other time [Lily]86-lily could have suggested reasonably tea , tobacco , newspapers . But this morning everything seemed so extraordinarily queer that a question like [Nancy]75-nancy 's - What does one send to [the Lighthouse]210-the lighthouse ? - opened doors in [one]222-one 's mind that went banging and swinging to and fro and made [one]222-one keep asking , in a stupefied gape , What does one send ? What does [one]222-one do ? Why is one sitting here , after all ?

Sitting alone for [Nancy]75-nancy went out again among the clean cups at the long table , [she]75-nancy felt cut off from [other people]332-other people , and able only to go on watching , asking , wondering . [The house]299-the house , [the place]888-the place , the morning , all seemed strangers to [her]75-nancy . [She]75-nancy had no attachment [here]361-here , [she]75-nancy felt , no relations with [it]1891-it , anything might happen , and whatever did happen , a step outside , a voice calling " It 's not in the cupboard ; it 's on [the landing]548-the landing , "[386-some one] [some one]386-some one cried , was a question , as if the link that usually bound things together had been cut , and they floated up here , down there , off , anyhow . How aimless it was , , how chaotic , how unreal it was , [she]75-nancy thought , looking at [her]75-nancy empty coffee cup . [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay dead ; [Andrew]173-andrew killed ; [Prue]174-miss prue dead too - repeat it as [she]75-nancy might , it roused no feeling in [her]75-nancy . And [we]1893-we all get together in [a house like this]1894-a house like this on a morning like this , [she]75-nancy said , looking out of the window . It was a beautiful still day .

2

Suddenly [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay raised [his]67-mr. ramsay head as [he]67-mr. ramsay passed and looked straight at [her]75-nancy , with [his]67-mr. ramsay distraught wild gaze which was yet so penetrating , as if [he]67-mr. ramsay saw [you]75-nancy , for one second , for the first time , for ever ; and [she]75-nancy pretended to drink out of [her]75-nancy empty coffee cup so as to escape [him]67-mr. ramsay - to escape [his]67-mr. ramsay demand on [her]75-nancy , to put aside a moment longer that imperious need . And [he]67-mr. ramsay shook [his]67-mr. ramsay head at [her]75-nancy , and strode on " Alone "[67-mr. ramsay] [she]75-nancy heard [him]67-mr. ramsay say , " Perished "[67-mr. ramsay] [she]75-nancy heard [him]67-mr. ramsay say and like everything else this strange morning the words became symbols , wrote themselves all over the grey - green walls . If only [she]75-nancy could put them together , [she]75-nancy felt , write them out in some sentence , then [she]75-nancy would have got at the truth of things . [Old Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael came padding softly in , fetched [his]80-mr. carmichael coffee , took [his]80-mr. carmichael cup and made off to sit in the sun . The extraordinary unreality was frightening ; but it was also exciting . Going to [the Lighthouse]210-the lighthouse . But what does one send to [the Lighthouse]210-the lighthouse ? Perished . Alone . The grey - green light on the wall opposite . [The empty places]1897-the empty places . Such were some of the parts , but how bring them together ? [she]75-nancy asked . As if any interruption would break the frail shape [she]75-nancy was building on the table [she]75-nancy turned [her]75-nancy back to the window lest [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay should see [her]75-nancy . [She]75-nancy must escape somewhere , be alone somewhere . Suddenly [she]75-nancy remembered . When [she]75-nancy had sat [there]236-there last ten years ago there had been a little sprig or leaf pattern on the table - cloth , which [she]75-nancy had looked at in a moment of revelation . There had been a problem about a foreground of a picture . Move the tree to the middle , [she]75-nancy had said . [She]75-nancy had never finished that picture . [She]75-nancy would paint that picture now . It had been knocking about in [her]75-nancy mind all these years . Where were [her]75-nancy paints , [she]75-nancy wondered ? [Her]75-nancy paints , yes . [She]75-nancy had left them in [the hall]914-the hall last night . [She]75-nancy would start at once . [She]75-nancy got up quickly , before [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay turned .

[She]75-nancy fetched [herself]75-nancy a chair . [She]75-nancy pitched [her]75-nancy easel with [her]75-nancy precise old - maidish movements on the edge of [the lawn]310-the lawn , not too close to [Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael , but close enough for [his]67-mr. ramsay protection . Yes , it must have been precisely here that [she]75-nancy had stood ten years ago . There was the wall ; the hedge ; the tree . The question was of some relation between [those masses]1901-those masses . [She]75-nancy had borne it in [her]75-nancy mind all these years . It seemed as if the solution had come to [her]75-nancy : [she]75-nancy knew now what [she]75-nancy wanted to do .

But with [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay bearing down on [her]75-nancy , [she]75-nancy could do nothing . Every time [he]67-mr. ramsay approached - [he]67-mr. ramsay was walking up and down [the terrace]225-the terrace - [ruin]1903-ruin approached , chaos approached . [She]75-nancy could not paint . [She]75-nancy stooped , [she]75-nancy turned ; [she]75-nancy took up this rag ; [she]75-nancy squeezed that tube . But all [she]75-nancy did was to ward [him]67-mr. ramsay off a moment . [He]67-mr. ramsay made it impossible for [her]75-nancy to do anything . For if [she]75-nancy gave [him]67-mr. ramsay the least chance , if [he]67-mr. ramsay saw [her]75-nancy disengaged a moment , looking [his]67-mr. ramsay way a moment , [he]67-mr. ramsay would be on [her]75-nancy , saying , as [he]67-mr. ramsay had said last night , " [You]75-nancy find [us]1904-they much changed . "[67-mr. ramsay] Last night [he]67-mr. ramsay had got up and stopped before [her]75-nancy , and said that . Dumb and staring though [they]1904-they had all sat , [the six children whom [they]1904-they used to call after [the Kings]181-the kings and Queens of [England]4-england]1905-the six children whom they used to call after the kings and queens of england - [the Red]182-the red , [the Fair]94-prue , [the Wicked]92-cam the wicked , [the Ruthless]93-james - [she]75-nancy felt how [they]1905-the six children whom they used to call after the kings and queens of england raged under it . Then , with [his]67-mr. ramsay hand on the door , [he]67-mr. ramsay stopped ; [he]67-mr. ramsay turned upon [them]1904-they . Did [they]1904-they not want to go ? [he]67-mr. ramsay demanded . [James]93-james was sixteen , [Cam]91-cam , seventeen , perhaps . [She]1912-she had looked round for [some one who was not there]1914-some one who was not there , for [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay , presumably . It was a wonderful night , starlit ; the waves sounded as [they]1904-they went [upstairs]375-upstairs ; the moon surprised [them]1904-they , enormous , pale , as [they]1904-they passed the staircase window . [She]1912-she had slept at once .

[She]1912-she set [her]1912-she clean canvas firmly upon the easel , as a barrier , frail , but [she]1912-she hoped sufficiently substantial to ward off [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay and [his]67-mr. ramsay exactingness . [She]1912-she rejected one brush ; [she]1912-she chose another . When would [those children]1918-those children come ? When would [they]1918-those children all be off ? [she]1912-she fidgeted . [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay had given . Giving , giving , giving , [she]65-mrs. ramsay had died - and had left all this . Really , [she]1912-she was angry with [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay . With the brush slightly trembling in [her]1912-she fingers [she]1912-she looked at the hedge , the step , the wall . It was all [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay 's doing . [She]65-mrs. ramsay was dead . [Here]361-here was [Lily]86-lily , at forty - four , wasting [her]86-lily time , unable to do a thing , standing there , playing at painting , playing at the one thing one did not play at , and it was all [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay 's fault . [She]65-mrs. ramsay was dead . The step where [she]65-mrs. ramsay used to sit was empty . [She]65-mrs. ramsay was dead .

But why repeat this over and over again ? Why be always trying to bring up some feeling [she]1912-she had not got ? There was a kind of blasphemy in it . It was all dry : all withered : all spent . [They]1922-they ought not to have asked [her]1912-she ; [she]1912-she ought not to have come . One ca n't waste [one]222-one 's time at forty- four , [she]1912-she thought . Here [he]1926-he was , close upon [her]1912-she again , greedy , distraught . Surely , [she]86-lily could imitate from recollection the glow , the rhapsody , the self - surrender , [she]86-lily had seen on [so many women]1927-so many women 's faces on [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay 's , for instance when on some occasion like this [they]1927-so many women blazed up - [she]86-lily could remember the look on [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay 's face - into a rapture of sympathy , of delight in the reward [they]1927-so many women had , which , though the reason of it escaped [her]86-lily , evidently conferred on [them]1927-so many women the most supreme bliss of which human nature was capable . 3

[She]1912-she seemed to have shrivelled slightly , [he]1926-he thought . [She]1912-she looked a little skimpy , wispy ; but not unattractive . [He]1926-he liked [her]1912-she . There had been some talk of [her]1912-she marrying [William Bankes]87-william bankes once , but nothing had come of it . [[His]1926-he wife]204-his wife had been fond of [her]1912-she . [He]1926-he had been a little out of temper too at breakfast . And then , and then - this was one of those moments when an enormous need urged [him]1926-he , without being conscious what it was , to approach [any woman]1929-any woman , to force [them]1929-any woman , [he]1926-he did not care how , [his]1926-he need was so great , to give [him]1926-he what [he]1926-he wanted : sympathy .

Was [anybody]416-anybody looking after [her]1912-she ? [he]1926-he said . Had [she]1912-she everything [she]1912-she wanted ?

" Oh , thanks , everything , "[86-lily] said [Lily Briscoe]86-lily nervously . No ; [she]86-lily could not do it . [She]1912-she ought to have floated off instantly upon some wave of sympathetic expansion : the pressure on [her]1912-she was tremendous . But [she]1912-she remained stuck . There was an awful pause . [They]1931-they both looked at [the sea]220-the sea . Why , thought [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay , should [she]1912-she look at [the sea]220-the sea when [I]0-i am here ? [The Lighthouse]210-the lighthouse ! What 's that got to do with it ? [he]67-mr. ramsay thought impatiently . Instantly , with the force of some primeval gust for really [he]67-mr. ramsay could not restrain [himself]67-mr. ramsay any longer , there issued from [him]67-mr. ramsay such a groan that [any other woman in [the whole world]800-the whole world]1936-any other woman in the whole world would have done something , said something - all except [myself]0-i , thought [Lily]86-lily , girding at [herself]86-lily bitterly , who am not [a woman]376-a woman , but [a peevish , ill - tempered , dried - up old maid]1939-a peevish , ill - tempered , dried - up old maid , presumably .

[Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay sighed to the full . [He]67-mr. ramsay waited . Was [she]1912-she not going to say anything ? Did [she]1912-she not see what [he]67-mr. ramsay wanted from [her]1912-she ? " Such expeditions , "[67-mr. ramsay] said [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay , scraping the ground with [his]67-mr. ramsay toe , " are very painful . "[67-mr. ramsay] Still [Lily]86-lily said nothing . " [They]1949-they are very exhausting , "[67-mr. ramsay] [he]67-mr. ramsay said , looking , with a sickly look that nauseated [her]86-lily [he]67-mr. ramsay was acting , [she]86-lily felt , [this great man]1948-this great man was dramatising [himself]67-mr. ramsay , at [his]67-mr. ramsay beautiful hands . It was horrible , it was indecent . Would [they]1949-they never come , [she]86-lily asked , for [she]86-lily could not sustain this enormous weight of sorrow , support these heavy draperies of grief [he]67-mr. ramsay had assumed a pose of extreme decreptitude ; [he]67-mr. ramsay even tottered a little as [he]67-mr. ramsay stood there a moment longer .

Still [she]86-lily could say nothing ; the whole horizon seemed swept bare of objects to talk about ; could only feel , amazedly , as [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay stood there , how [his]67-mr. ramsay gaze seemed to fall dolefully over the sunny grass and discolour it , and cast over the rubicund , drowsy , entirely contented figure of [Mr. Carmichael]80-mr. carmichael , reading a French novel on a deck - chair , a veil of crape , as if such an existence , flaunting its prosperity in [a world of woe]1950-a world of woe , were enough to provoke the most dismal thoughts of all . Ah , could that bulk only be wafted alongside of [them]1949-they , [Lily]86-lily wished ; had [she]86-lily only pitched [her]86-lily easel a yard or two closer to [him]67-mr. ramsay ; [a man]1103-a man , [any man]1952-any man , would staunch this effusion , would stop these lamentations . It was immensely to [her]86-lily discredit , sexually , to stand there dumb . [One]222-one said - what did [one]222-one say ? - Oh , [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay ! [Dear Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay ! [His]67-mr. ramsay immense self - pity , [his]67-mr. ramsay demand for sympathy poured and spread itself in pools at ther feet , and all [she]86-lily did , miserable sinner that [she]86-lily was , was to draw [her]86-lily skirts a little closer round [her]86-lily ankles , lest [she]86-lily should get wet . Heaven could never be sufficiently praised ! [She]86-lily heard sounds in [the house]299-the house . [James]93-james and [Cam]91-cam must be coming . But [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay , as if [he]67-mr. ramsay knew that [his]67-mr. ramsay time ran short , exerted upon [her]86-lily solitary figure the immense pressure of [his]67-mr. ramsay concentrated woe ; [his]67-mr. ramsay age ; [his]67-mr. ramsay frailty : [his]67-mr. ramsay desolation ; when suddenly , tossing [his]67-mr. ramsay head impatiently , in [his]67-mr. ramsay annoyance - for after all , [what woman]1961-what woman could resist [him]67-mr. ramsay ? - [he]67-mr. ramsay noticed that [his]67-mr. ramsay boot - laces were untied . Remarkable boots they were too , [Lily]86-lily thought , looking down at them : sculptured ; colossal ; like everything that [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay wore , from [his]67-mr. ramsay frayed tie to [his]67-mr. ramsay half - buttoned waistcoat , [his]67-mr. ramsay own indisputably . " What beautiful boots ! "[86-lily] [she]86-lily exclaimed . [She]86-lily was ashamed of [herself]86-lily . To praise [his]67-mr. ramsay boots when [he]67-mr. ramsay asked [her]86-lily to solace [his]67-mr. ramsay soul ; when [he]67-mr. ramsay had shown [her]86-lily [his]67-mr. ramsay bleeding hands , [his]67-mr. ramsay lacerated heart , and asked [her]86-lily to pity them , then to say , cheerfully , " Ah , but what beautiful boots [you]67-mr. ramsay wear ! "[67-mr. ramsay] deserved , [she]86-lily knew , and [she]86-lily looked up expecting to get it in one of [his]67-mr. ramsay sudden roars of ill - temper complete annihilation .

Instead , [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay smiled . [His]67-mr. ramsay pall , [his]67-mr. ramsay draperies , [his]67-mr. ramsay infirmities fell from [him]67-mr. ramsay . Ah , yes , [he]67-mr. ramsay said , holding [his]67-mr. ramsay foot up for [her]86-lily to look at , they were first - rate boots . There was [only one man in [England]4-england]1964-only one man in england who could make boots like that . [Boots]183-boots are among the chief curses of [mankind]1730-mankind , [he]67-mr. ramsay said . " [Bootmakers]2868-bootmakers make it [their]2868-bootmakers business , "[67-mr. ramsay] [he]67-mr. ramsay exclaimed , " to cripple and torture the human foot . "[67-mr. ramsay] [They]1966-they are also [the most obstinate and perverse of mankind]1967-the most obstinate and perverse of mankind . It had taken [him]67-mr. ramsay the best part of [his]67-mr. ramsay youth to get boots made as they should be made . [He]67-mr. ramsay would have [her]86-lily observe [he]67-mr. ramsay lifted [his]67-mr. ramsay right foot and then [his]67-mr. ramsay left that [she]86-lily had never seen boots made quite that shape before . They were made of the finest leather in [the world]300-the world , also . Most leather was mere brown paper and cardboard . [He]67-mr. ramsay looked complacently at [his]67-mr. ramsay foot , still held in the air . [They]1969-they had reached , [she]86-lily felt , [a sunny island where peace dwelt , sanity reigned and the sun for ever shone]1970-a sunny island where peace dwelt , sanity reigned and the sun for ever shone , [the blessed island of good boots]1971-the blessed island of good boots . [Her]86-lily heart warmed to [him]67-mr. ramsay . " Now let [me]67-mr. ramsay see if [you]86-lily can tie a knot , "[67-mr. ramsay] [he]67-mr. ramsay said . [He]67-mr. ramsay poohpoohed [her]86-lily feeble system . [He]67-mr. ramsay showed [her]86-lily [his]67-mr. ramsay own invention . Once [you]1972-you tied it , it never came undone . Three times [he]67-mr. ramsay knotted [her]86-lily shoe ; three times [he]67-mr. ramsay unknotted it .

Why , at this completely inappropriate moment , when [he]67-mr. ramsay was stooping over [her]86-lily shoe , should [she]86-lily be so tormented with sympathy for [him]67-mr. ramsay that , as [she]86-lily stooped too , the blood rushed to [her]86-lily face , and , thinking of [her]86-lily callousness [she]86-lily had called [him]67-mr. ramsay a play - actor [she]86-lily felt [her]86-lily eyes swell and tingle with tears ? Thus occupied [he]67-mr. ramsay seemed to [her]86-lily a figure of infinite pathos . [He]67-mr. ramsay tied knots . [He]67-mr. ramsay bought boots . There was no helping [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay on the journey [he]67-mr. ramsay was going . But now just as [she]86-lily wished to say something , could have said something , perhaps , here [they]1973-they were - [Cam]91-cam and [James]93-james . [They]1973-they appeared on [the terrace]225-the terrace . [They]1973-they came , lagging , side by side , [a serious , melancholy couple]1975-a serious , melancholy couple .

But why was it like THAT that [they]1973-they came ? [She]86-lily could not help feeling annoyed with [them]1973-they ; [they]1973-they might have come more cheerfully ; [they]1973-they might have given [him]67-mr. ramsay what , now that [they]1973-they were off , [she]86-lily would not have the chance of giving [him]67-mr. ramsay . For [she]86-lily felt a sudden emptiness ; a frustration . [Her]86-lily feeling had come too late ; there it was ready ; but [he]67-mr. ramsay no longer needed it . [He]67-mr. ramsay had become [a very distinguished , elderly man]1976-a very distinguished , elderly man , who had no need of [her]86-lily whatsoever . [She]86-lily felt snubbed . [He]67-mr. ramsay slung a knapsack round [his]67-mr. ramsay shoulders . [He]67-mr. ramsay shared out the parcels - there were a number of them , ill tied in brown paper . [He]67-mr. ramsay sent [Cam]91-cam for a cloak . [He]67-mr. ramsay had all the appearance of [a leader making ready for an expedition]1977-a leader making ready for an expedition . Then , wheeling about , [he]67-mr. ramsay led the way with [his]67-mr. ramsay firm military tread , in those wonderful boots , carrying brown paper parcels , down [the path]2758-the path , [[his]67-mr. ramsay children]202-his children following [him]67-mr. ramsay . [They]202-his children looked , [she]86-lily thought , as if fate had devoted [them]202-his children to some stern enterprise , and [they]202-his children went to it , still young enough to be drawn acquiescent in [[their]202-his children father]1516-their father 's wake , obediently , but with a pallor in [their]202-his children eyes which made [her]86-lily feel that [they]202-his children suffered something beyond [their]202-his children years in silence . So [they]202-his children passed the edge of [the lawn]310-the lawn , and it seemed to [Lily]86-lily that [she]86-lily watched a procession go , drawn on by some stress of common feeling which made it , faltering and flagging as it was , [a little company]1982-a little company bound together and strangely impressive to [her]86-lily . Politely , but very distantly , [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay raised [his]67-mr. ramsay hand and saluted [her]86-lily as [they]202-his children passed .

But what a face , [she]86-lily thought , immediately finding the sympathy which [she]86-lily had not been asked to give troubling [her]86-lily for expression . What had made it like that ? Thinking , night after night , [she]86-lily supposed - about the reality of [kitchen tables]1983-kitchen tables , [she]86-lily added , remembering the symbol which in [her]86-lily vagueness as to what [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay did think about [Andrew]173-andrew had given [her]86-lily . [He]67-mr. ramsay had been killed by the splinter of a shell instantly , [she]86-lily bethought [her]86-lily . The kitchen table was something visionary , austere ; something bare , hard , not ornamental . There was no colour to it ; it was all edges and angles ; it was uncompromisingly plain . But [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay kept always [his]67-mr. ramsay eyes fixed upon it , never allowed [himself]67-mr. ramsay to be distracted or deluded , until [his]67-mr. ramsay face became worn too and ascetic and partook of this unornamented beauty which so deeply impressed [her]86-lily . Then , [she]86-lily recalled standing where [he]67-mr. ramsay had left [her]86-lily , holding [her]86-lily brush , worries had fretted it - not so nobly . [He]67-mr. ramsay must have had [his]67-mr. ramsay doubts about that table , [she]86-lily supposed ; whether the table was a real table ; whether it was worth the time [he]67-mr. ramsay gave to it ; whether [he]67-mr. ramsay was able after all to find it . [He]67-mr. ramsay had had doubts , [she]86-lily felt , or [he]67-mr. ramsay would have asked less of [people]264-people . That was what [they]1985-they talked about late at night sometimes , [she]86-lily suspected ; and then next day [Mrs. Ramsay]65-mrs. ramsay looked tired , and [Lily]86-lily flew into a rage with [him]67-mr. ramsay over some absurd little thing . But now [he]67-mr. ramsay had [nobody to talk to about that table]1986-nobody to talk to about that table , or [his]67-mr. ramsay boots , or [his]67-mr. ramsay knots ; and [he]67-mr. ramsay was like a lion seeking whom [he]67-mr. ramsay could devour , and [his]67-mr. ramsay face had that touch of desperation , of exaggeration in it which alarmed [her]86-lily , and made [her]86-lily pull [her]86-lily skirts about [her]86-lily . And then , [she]86-lily recalled , there was that sudden revivification , that sudden flare when [she]86-lily praised [his]67-mr. ramsay boots , that sudden recovery of vitality and interest in ordinary human things , which too passed and changed for [he]67-mr. ramsay was always changing , and hid nothing into that other final phase which was new to [her]86-lily and had , [she]86-lily owned , made [herself]86-lily ashamed of [her]86-lily own irritability , when it seemed as if [he]67-mr. ramsay had shed worries and ambitions , and the hope of sympathy and the desire for praise , had entered some other region , was drawn on , as if by curiosity , in dumb colloquy , whether with [himself]67-mr. ramsay or another , at the head of [that little procession out of one 's range]1987-that little procession out of one 's range . An extraordinary face ! The gate banged .

4

So [they]1988-they 're gone , [she]86-lily thought , sighing with relief and disappointment . [Her]86-lily sympathy seemed to be cast back on [her]86-lily , like a bramble sprung across [her]86-lily face . [She]86-lily felt curiously divided , as if one part of [her]86-lily were drawn out there - it was a still day , hazy ; [the Lighthouse]49-the lighthouse looked this morning at an immense distance ; the other had fixed itself doggedly , solidly , here on [the lawn]310-the lawn . [She]86-lily saw [her]86-lily canvas as if it had floated up and placed itself white and uncompromising directly before [her]86-lily . [It]1990-it seemed to rebuke [her]86-lily with its cold stare for all this hurry and agitation ; this folly and waste of emotion ; it drastically recalled [her]86-lily and spread through [her]86-lily mind first a peace , as [her]86-lily disorderly sensations [he]67-mr. ramsay had gone and [she]86-lily had been so sorry for [him]67-mr. ramsay and [she]86-lily had said nothing trooped off [the field]769-the field ; and then , emptiness . [She]86-lily looked blankly at the canvas , with its uncompromising white stare ; from the canvas to [the garden]371-the garden . There was something [she]86-lily stood screwing up [her]86-lily little Chinese eyes in [her]86-lily small puckered face , something [she]86-lily remembered in the relations of those lines cutting across , slicing down , and in the mass of the hedge with its green cave of blues and browns , which had stayed in [her]86-lily mind ; which had tied a knot in [her]86-lily mind so that at odds and ends of time , involuntarily , as [she]86-lily walked along [the Brompton Road]438-the brompton road , as [she]86-lily brushed [her]86-lily hair , [she]86-lily found [herself]86-lily painting that picture , passing [her]86-lily eye over it , and untying the knot in imagination . But there was all the difference in [the world]300-the world between this planning airily away from the canvas and actually taking [her]86-lily brush and making the first mark .

[She]86-lily had taken the wrong brush in [her]86-lily agitation at [Mr. Ramsay]67-mr. ramsay 's presence , and [her]86-lily easel , rammed into the earth so nervously , was at the wrong angle . And now that [she]86-lily had ut that right , and in so doing had subdued the impertinences and irrelevances that plucked [her]86-lily attention and made [her]86-lily remember how [she]86-lily was such and such [a person]1995-a person , had such and such relations to [people]264-people , [she]86-lily took [her]86-lily hand and raised [her]86-lily brush . For a moment it stayed trembling in a painful but exciting ecstasy in the air . Where to begin ? - that was the question at what point to make the first mark ? One line placed on the canvas committed [her]86-lily to innumerable risks , to frequent and irrevocable decisions . All that in idea seemed simple became in practice immediately complex ; as the waves shape themselves symmetrically from the cliff top , but to the swimmer among [them]1997-them are divided by steep gulfs , and foaming crests . Still the risk must be run ; the mark made .
